feed.title: Code and Unload by Codio
feed.subtitle: While we code we often have lots of ideas brewing around. Ideas we'd like to unload onto you

entry.title: From the Front-line - #10
entry.summary:
I neglected to post on Friday, so today is a bumper double issue thingy...

  • Need to track and report on your Javascript exceptions? You won't get better than Errorception, which we use ourselves.

  • Like JSHint? Then you should love ESHint, which is a...
entry.content:
I neglected to post on Friday, so today is a bumper double issue thingy...

  • Need to track and report on your Javascript exceptions? You won't get better than Errorception, which we use ourselves.

  • Like JSHint? Then you should love ESHint, which is a linting tool where all rules are pluggable.

  • Need to expand and collapse blocks of text with a link? Check out ReadMore.js.

  • Oh look! Another "Bootstrap wannabe" CSS framework, this time called Cardinal, which apparently is small and mobile first.

  • Spectacular is a good looking RSpec inspired BDD framework for Javascript and CoffeeScript.

  • Need to run A/B tests? easyAB is a jQuery/Zepto plugin may be just want you need.

  • Give users real time hints and progress updates as they complete your forms with Progression.js.

  • WebRTC is one of the most technically advanced offerings to become built right into the browser. simpleWebRTC might just make it a little easier to implement.

  • Great article In defence of Javascript's Constructors.

My goal is to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.

entry.title: From the Front-line - #9
entry.summary:
Here's today's juicy bundle of links...

  • I mentioned the emerging Effekt.css back in issue #1, but it seems they've been busy and we now have a good number of effects ready to go.

  • While researching ways to improve Codio's own internal Javascript routing
entry.content:
Here's today's juicy bundle of links...

  • I mentioned the emerging Effekt.css back in issue #1, but it seems they've been busy and we now have a good number of effects ready to go.

  • While researching ways to improve Codio's own internal Javascript routing system, I came across Router.js, which is the router that EmberJS uses. It's a very thorough implementation.

  • Lots of talk around ES6, the next version of EcmaScript (Javascript), but this slideshow talks about the awesome parts.

  • screenfull.js is a tiny wrapper for cross-browser usage of the Javascript fullscreen API, which lets you bring the page or any element into fullscreen.

  • Nice post by our friend Dave Taylor on the awesomeness that is JSHint.

  • Later.js claims to be the simplest way to work with recurring schedules. If you're only talking about Javascript, then they're probably right.

My goal is to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.

entry.title: From the Front-line - #8
entry.summary:
A little quiet today...

  • Lovely little bookmarklet or DevTools snippet for Chrome that logs your global Javascript variables to the console.

  • Completely useless, but awesome nonetheless, face to gif lets you record yourself and produces an animated...
entry.content:
A little quiet today...

  • Lovely little bookmarklet or DevTools snippet for Chrome that logs your global Javascript variables to the console.

  • Completely useless, but awesome nonetheless, face to gif lets you record yourself and produces an animated gif.

  • responseImg is a jQuery plugin that turns your img tags into responsive images with retina alternatives.

  • Really love these CSS3 animated books.

My goal is to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.

entry.title: From the Front-line - #7
entry.summary:
Almost forgot today...

  • A great selection of front-end optimisations you can start doing right now.

  • Not sure why we would want yet another Javascript framework, but Minified is less than 4kb in size, so at least it lives up to its name.

  • Oh and look...
entry.content:
Almost forgot today...

  • A great selection of front-end optimisations you can start doing right now.

  • Not sure why we would want yet another Javascript framework, but Minified is less than 4kb in size, so at least it lives up to its name.

  • Oh and look... another new JS framework called Q.js that contains "a lot of useful Javascript functions"!

  • Great article on CSS-Tricks about the extend concept in the three big CSS preprocessors.

  • Need help with your CSS animations? Stylie is a fun CSS animation tool that could save you time, and might just be what you need.

  • David Walsh does it again... again - 9 mind blowing WebGL demos. (the Chrome world maze is my fave!)

My goal is to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.

entry.title: From the Front-line - #6
entry.summary:
A new week, another five issues...

  • StructuredJS is a JS library that provides an interface for checking the structure of your code. Written by the Khan Academy to teach coding, but I'm not so sure how useful this is elsewhere.

  • Writing documentation...
entry.content:
A new week, another five issues...

  • StructuredJS is a JS library that provides an interface for checking the structure of your code. Written by the Khan Academy to teach coding, but I'm not so sure how useful this is elsewhere.

  • Writing documentation should be easy, Daux.io does a pretty good job of that by basing it on a simple document structure and Markdown files.

  • I see a lot of demos demonstrating the power of the latest JS/HTML/CSS, but this one of a Minion written only in HTML and CSS is just freakin' awesome!

  • If you like the life-saving PhantomJS, then you'll love PhantomCSS, which is "An integration of Resemble.js with PhantomJS and CasperJS for automating visual regression testing of Website styling to support refactoring of CSS". A mouthful, but still pretty cool.

  • It's amazing how extremely useful Chrome's Dev Tools have become. This post on HTML5 Rocks, recaps the latest and greatest, including Workspaces, SASS debugging, Flame Charts and remote debugging.

  • Building in Open Source? If so, you should check out ChooseALicense.com; a new site from the Github guys, which helps you decide which OSS license to use.

My goal is to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.

entry.title: From the Front-line - #5
entry.summary:
And here endeth our final day of the week, and the fifth issue...

  • Been working with Media Queries for the redesign of this site, and came across a need to react to media queries in Javascript. Unfortunately that's not possible, because it's only CSS...
entry.content:
And here endeth our final day of the week, and the fifth issue...

  • Been working with Media Queries for the redesign of this site, and came across a need to react to media queries in Javascript. Unfortunately that's not possible, because it's only CSS. I found enquire.js does exactly that. Bonus!

  • A little gem of an article for running synchronised testing between browsers/devices using Grunt.

  • Eddy is a nifty little Javascript Event library that gives the familiar on, and off methods but on any and every Object.

  • Chrome Developer Tools just keep getting better and better. In the latest Chrome Canary, you'll find a awesome feature called Snippets, which let you save and reuse small bits of code within the console. Kind of like the Snippets that we have available in Codio, but not awesome!

  • TreeModel A very intuitive Javascript library for manipulating and traversing tree-like structures. It has some great demo's on its site.

  • An oldie, but a goodie... This is Responsive is a site full of patterns, resources and new for creating responsive web experiences.

  • And finally, a nice little nugget for queuing your Ajax requests.

My goal is to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.
